question: Question_02_(b)
statement:
\textbf{Integration: Short Answer Problems - Evaluate the following
integrals: state if a definite integral does not exist; use limits for
improper integrals. (full marks for correct answer; work must be shown
for partial marks)}

$\displaystyle I_b = \int \arctan\big(\tfrac{1}{x}\big)\,dx$
sols:
Proceeding as in the hint, let
$\displaystyle u=\arctan\big(\tfrac{1}{x}\big)$ and
$\displaystyle dv = dx$. Then via the chain rule, we have
$\displaystyle du = \frac{\tfrac{-1}{x^2}}{\tfrac{1}{x^2} + 1} = \frac{-1}{x^2+1}$
and $\displaystyle v=x$ so integrating by parts gives us

\begin{align*}
I_b &=  \int \arctan\big(\tfrac{1}{x}\big)\,dx \\
&= x\arctan\big(\tfrac{1}{x}\big) -\int \frac{-x}{x^2+1}\,dx\end{align*}

Now let $\displaystyle w = x^2+1$ so that $\displaystyle dw = 2x \ dx$
and thus the above becomes after substitution

\begin{align*}
I_b &= x\arctan\big(\tfrac{1}{x}\big) +\int \frac{x}{x^2+1}\,dx\\
&= x\arctan\big(\tfrac{1}{x}\big) + \int \frac{dw}{2w}\\
&= x\arctan\big(\tfrac{1}{x}\big) + \frac{1}{2} \cdot \ln|w| + C\\
&= x\arctan\big(\tfrac{1}{x}\big) + \frac{1}{2} \cdot \ln|x^2+1| + C\end{align*}
hints: This is a special case of integration by parts.
